text.front:
IOP PUBLISHING
PLASMA SOURCES SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045003 (9pp)
doi:10.1088/0963-0252/20/4/045003
Internal current measurements in high
power impulse magnetron sputtering
Daniel Lundin 1 , Seham Al Sahab 1 , Nils Brenning 2 , Chunqing Huo 2 and
Ulf Helmersson 1
1 Plasma and Coatings Physics Division, IFM-Materials Physics, Linköping University, SE-581 83
Linköping, Sweden
2 Division of Space and Plasma Physics, School of Electrical Engineering, Royal Institute of Technology,
SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden
E-mail: daniel.lundin@liu.se
Received 30 November 2010, in final form 4 April 2011
Published 25 May 2011
Online at stacks.iop.org/PSST/20/045003
Abstract
The transport of charged particles in a high power impulse magnetron sputtering (HiPIMS)
discharge is of considerable interest when optimizing this promising deposition technique with
respect to deposition rate and control of the ion acceleration. In this study the internal current
densities J ϕ (azimuthal direction) and J z (axial direction) have therefore been spatially and
temporally resolved in the bulk plasma region above a cylindrical magnetron using Rogowski
coils. From the measurements a phenomenological model has been constructed describing the
evolution of the current density in this pulsed plasma. The core of the model is based on three
different types of current systems, which characterize the operating transport mechanisms,
such as current transport along and across magnetic field lines. There is a gradual change
between these current systems during the initiation, build-up and steady state of a HiPIMS
plasma. Furthermore, the data also show that there are spatial and temporal variations of the
key transport parameter J ϕ /J z , governing the cross-B resistivity and also the energy of the
charged particles. The previously reported faster-than-Bohm cross-B electron transport is
verified here, but not for all locations. These results on the plasma dynamics are essential input
when modeling the axial electric field, governing the back-attraction of ionized sputtered
material, and might furthermore provide a link between the different resistivities reported in
HiPIMS, pulsed-DC, and DC magnetron discharges.
(Some figures in this article are in colour only in the electronic version)
text.body:
1. Introduction
High power impulse magnetron sputtering (HiPIMS)
introduced by Kouznetsov et al in 1999 [1] is a promising
technique for improving magnetron sputtering used in many
industrial processes for thin film deposition [2]. The HiPIMS
discharge generates a highly ionized plasma with large
quantities of energetic metal ions [3] due to very high pulse
power densities with, in some cases, a directed flux of charged
species [4]. The high degree of ionization of the sputtered
species has several advantages for thin film growth, such as
an increased density [5] and adhesion [6], in particular for
complex-shaped surfaces [7, 8], and a decreased deposition
temperature [9].
The high potential applied to the magnetron in a HiPIMS
discharge generates large internal currents in the plasma
between the sputtering cathode and the anode (often the
chamber walls and the ground shield of the magnetron). Large
azimuthal currents, circulating in the magnetic field trap close
to the target surface, also arise due to the presence of the
magnetic field [10]. Measurements by Bohlmark et al [11]
show that the ratio between the azimuthal Hall current density,
J H , and the cross-B discharge current density, J D⊥ , in a typical
HiPIMS process is surprisingly low, meaning a high speed in
the electron transport across the magnetic field lines during
the HiPIMS discharge. This so-called anomalous transport
is known to also affect the transport of ions in this type
of discharge [4] and has recently been investigated in more
text.front:
0963-0252/11/045003+09$33.00
1
© 2011 IOP Publishing Ltd Printed in the UK & the USA
Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045003
D Lundin et al
text.body:
detail using electric probes [10] to estimate the azimuthal
current, J ϕ . From these studies it was concluded that the
current density ratio was typically J ϕ /J D⊥ ≈ 2. This value
is significantly lower than what is expected from classical
theory of diffusion and electrical conductivity using collisions
to move electrons across the magnetic field, or even Bohm
diffusion seen in common direct current magnetron sputtering
(DCMS) [10]. Expected values for the Bohm regime is
in the range 8 < J ϕ /J D⊥ < 30 [12, 13]. Moreover, in a
recent series of experiments and simulations [10, 14] it was
proposed that the anomalous transport could be described
as being mediated by highly nonlinear waves, likely due
to the modified two-stream instability (MTSI), resulting in
electric field oscillations in the MHz-range. Furthermore, the
ratio J ϕ /J D⊥ can in the magnetron geometry be identified
with the more general Hall parameter ω ge τ EFF [10]. Here
ω ge is the electron (angular) gyrofrequency and τ EFF is the
effective electron-ion momentum transfer time. In a study by
Brenning et al [15] analyzing three different types of pulsed
plasma discharges (including HiPIMS) of different magnetic
geometries, as well as covering several orders of magnitude
in plasma density, it was found that the faster-than-Bohm
anomalous transport is present in all cases and is expressed by
ω ge τ EFF = 2.7 within a factor of 2. This gives an approximate
faster-than-Bohm transport range 1.5 < ω ge τ EFF < 5.5.
In summary, previous investigations have provided
important insights into understanding the mechanism behind
the anomalous transport, but still it is likely that the same pulsed
discharge can undergo different transport types in different
parts of the plasma as well as during different stages of
the pulse. In order to fully understand the transport of the
energetic charged particles it is necessary to both spatially
and temporally resolve what type of transport mechanism that
operates in the HiPIMS discharge. In this study the current
densities J ϕ and J z have therefore been directly measured
using Rogowski coils, which, unlike electrical probes, require
no further information regarding the plasma characteristics in
order to determine the current flowing in a particular direction.
The current density ratio, J ϕ /J z , has also been calculated
and is here presented for different locations in the plasma as
well as for different times during the pulse. Above the race
track the magnetic field is approximately parallel to the target,
J z ≈ J D⊥ , and the measured current density ratio gives the
Hall parameter: J ϕ /J z ≈ J ϕ /J D⊥ = ω ge τ EFF .
2. Experimental details
The experiments were carried out using a standard, circular,
slightly unbalanced, planar magnetron source equipped with
a high-purity copper (Cu) target with a diameter of 0.150 m.
The magnetic null point is located about 0.10 m from the target
surface and the target race track is approximately located at ρ =
4.5 cm. A complete description of the magnetic field topology
of the present magnetron setup has been given by Bohlmark
et al [11]. The magnetron (cathode) was located inside
a stainless steel vacuum chamber (height 0.70 m, diameter
0.44 m). The chamber walls and the ground shield of the
magnetron served as an anode for the discharge. The base
Figure 1. Voltage and current characteristic for a typical HiPIMS
discharge pulse used in the study.
pressure was maintained around 1.33 × 10 −4 Pa using a turbo
molecular pump. Argon with a minimum purity of 99.9997%
was used as a discharge gas and introduced into the chamber
through a mass flow controller. The argon pressure was kept
constant at 0.53 Pa.
Unipolar pulses were applied between the cathode (target)
and the chamber walls using a HiPIMS Sinex 3 (Chemfilt
Ionsputtering AB, Sweden) power supply capable of delivering
2000 V and 1200 A peak values. In this work pulses up
to approximately 800 V and 145 A were used with a pulse
duration of 200 µs and a repetition frequency of 100 Hz, as
seen in figure 1.
In this work Rogowski coils [16] were used for measuring
the current density (see figure 2). The probe consists of a
helical coil of wire with the lead from one end returning through
the center of the coil to the other end, so that both terminals are
at the same end of the coil in order to eliminate contributions
from external components of the current. The Rogowski
coil has no ferromagnetic material in the core, which means
that the coil cannot be driven into saturation and therefore
responds linearly to extremely large currents [17]. Being of
low inductance it can also respond to very high frequency
pulses, and thus making it suitable as a plasma diagnostics tool
in HiPIMS discharges. The probe was mounted on a movable
metal rod for scans taken at different axial (z) as well as radial
(ρ) positions. In this work z = 0 marks the target surface and ρ
is measured from the center axis of the target. The center of the
probe torus was chosen to define the probe position. The probe
was never moved closer than z = 4 cm in order not to disturb
the plasma discharge, which was verified by continuously
recording the discharge characteristics (the voltage and current
curves) and only using data from probe positions where these
were not influenced as the probe was moved toward the cathode
surface. The probe and rod could be rotated in order to measure
directional currents. In the present investigation the axial as
well as azimuthal current profiles were determined in the region
4 z 8 cm and 0 ρ 7.5 cm assuming axial symmetry.
Data were collected at 1 cm intervals in the axial direction and
at four different points in the radial direction (ρ = 0, 2.5,
4.5, 7.5 cm), constituting a total of 20 different locations in the
plasma.
text.note:
Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045003
D Lundin et al
text.body:
R
r
Figure 2. Schematic of the geometry of the internal windings of a
Rogowski probe used in the experiments displaying the copper wire
wound around a rigid non-magnetic core made of PVC plastic and
attached to a ceramic tube. The copper wire has been back wound
and fed through the ceramic tube. R = 21.5 mm is the outer radius
and r = 9.7 mm is the inner radius of the probe. Before mounting
the probe in the chamber the torus was covered with a thin layer of
epoxy glue (torr-seal). Finally a thin layer of copper was deposited
on the probe as an electrostatic shield.
A Rogowski coil produces a voltage signal [16] given as
V coil =
nAµ 0
2πr
dI
dt
,
(1)
where n is the number of turns, A is the cross-sectional area
for each turn, r is the major radius of the coil torus and I is
the current through it. The probe signal is integrated to yield
the current as function of time. It is not possible to measure
DC currents with this type of probe, since the voltage that is
induced in the coil is proportional to the rate of change of the
current.
In the present experiments a Rogowski coil, where the
shield had inner radius of 9.7 mm and outer radius of 21.5 mm,
was inserted into the plasma (figure 2). The current density
was obtained from the measured total current by assuming
an effective collection radius of 15.6 mm, with an estimated
error of 50% due to the uncertainty of how the current pattern
is influenced by the probe: deflected around the probe torus,
or compressed into it. In order to estimate the accuracy of
the recorded current densities the total axial current flowing
across a disk at z = 4 cm (0
ρ
7.5) was measured
and compared with the discharge current. It cannot be proven
certain that a measurement at this distance captures the full
discharge current, but it was the best option with respect to
stable plasma discharge conditions since, at probe position
closer to the target than 4 cm, the discharge voltage and current
characteristics were influenced. From the comparison of the
absolute values it was found that they are of the same order
within a factor of two given the assumed current collection
area of the probe, and thus in line with the assumed uncertainty.
The only exception is toward the end of the pulse, where the
recorded probe current is slightly higher. This deviation is
addressed in section 3.2 regarding the analysis of the different
current systems. Still it must be pointed out that it is not the
absolute values in this type of discharge, but the topology
of the current density distribution which is the focus of the
present investigation. For these we only need to assume that
the effective collection area of the probe is not dependent on
direction. Conclusions regarding the current patterns, as well
as the J ϕ /J z ratio, are therefore less uncertain than the absolute
values.
The probe winding consisted of 0.2 mm copper wire
around a rigid plastic toroidal core making up a total of 470
turns. The probe was calibrated several times throughout the
whole series of measurements by recording a known sinusoidal
current running through the center of the probe together with
the probe output. The probe signal was later integrated and
manually fitted to the current signal. From the calibration it
was concluded that the probe provided very good accuracy up
to 1 MHz, and thus meeting the experimental requirements.
The inductance of the probe was found to be approximately
0.66 µH, which was calculated based on the given probe
dimensions. Furthermore, careful precautions were taken to
minimize the system noise, which meant adding additional
shielding to cables from the turbo pump as well as control
units. In this way the maximum noise level was found to
be less than 5% by measuring the probe signal inside the
chamber with no other process running during operation. Basic
plasma parameters such as target voltage and target current as
well as the probe signal were monitored and recorded on a
Tektronix TDS2004B oscilloscope. A Tektronix P6015 high
voltage probe measured the target voltage. The current was
measured with a Chauvin Arnoux C160 current probe. All
signals recorded were averaged over 128 measurements to
ensure better statistics.
3. Results and discussion
3.1. Internal current distributions
The internal currents J ϕ and J z in a typical HiPIMS discharge
were measured in the ranges 4
z
8 cm and 0
ρ
7.5 cm. An example of a time-resolved current density curve
of the J ϕ component taken at z = 7 cm and ρ = 4.5 cm is given
in figure 3. The letters (a)-(e) indicate the different times where
current density maps have been generated. The most striking
features are the two peaks present at about 60 and 130 µs. They
were seen in all measurements, although the magnitude of the
individual peaks as well as the relative magnitude between the
two peaks shifted depending on location. The time of the first
peak always coincides with the peak of the discharge current
for both J ϕ and J z . Table 1 summarizes the different features
for the chosen points in time.
In order to facilitate the interpretation of the evolving
internal currents present during the HiPIMS discharge, 2D

D Lundin et al

Figure 3. A typical internal current density measurement generated
by integrating the signal from the Rogowski coil. The letters (a)-(e)
indicate the different times where current density maps have been
created. This particular profile was recorded when measuring J ϕ at
z = 7 cm and ρ = 4.5 cm (i.e. above the target race track).
Table 1. A summary of the features seen in the discharge current as
well as the general trends for a typical internal current density
measurement for five different stages of the HiPIMS pulse. The
points (a)-(e) are plotted as current density maps for the investigated
region (see figures 4(a)-(e)).

current density maps have been generated based on the results
from the measurements. These maps are given in figures 4(a)-
(e), where the letter stands for the same point in time as seen
in table 1. The left panel is the measured J ϕ , the middle
panel represents J z , and the right panel is the current density
ratio J ϕ /J z . Since the color coding varies between these
current density plots, they have for clarity been provided with a
scale factor in the upper left corner indicating the approximate
current density increase compared with figure 4(a). Given
below is first a description of the currents measured during the
HiPIMS discharge, which is followed by an analysis of the
internal current system.
Following the time evolution of the internal currents it is
seen in the middle panel of figure 4(a) that only small axial
currents are flowing above z = 4 cm during the initial part of
the HiPIMS discharge (t < 30 µs). From the J z plot at 30 µs
it can be concluded that most of the current is transported from
the center and outer edges of the magnetron to the nearest
anode point along the magnetic field lines and that little axial
cross-B transport is present above the race track region. At the
same time a clearly distinguished azimuthal current is flowing
in a torus 5 cm above the target race track. This is in line with
electron density measurements by Bohlmark et al [18] on the
same system, where they recorded a toroidal-shaped density
increase at the same time and place. Also, in a previous study
on Hall currents using the same setup (but a Ta target) it was
measured that, in the early phase of the discharge (at 16 µs),
J ϕ reached values around 10-20 kA m −2 at 4-6 cm above the
target race track for 5-6 times the discharge current (∼300-
350 A) compared with the present investigation (60 A) [11].
The left panel of figure 4(a) shows slightly less than a quarter
of that value, which is consistent with our lower discharge
current. Moreover, it is seen that further away from the cathode
surface (z > 6 cm) both J ϕ and J z are of the same magnitude,
indicating that here is a region of much larger cross-B transport
(i.e. lower Hall parameter ω ge τ EFF ).
At the peak of the discharge current (t = 60 µs) the
azimuthal current is fully developed and reaches values around
22 kA m −2 above the target race track (figure 4(b)), which is
a tenfold increase compared with t = 30 µs. J z has now also
developed in the region above the target race track, although
it only amounts to about twice the increase in magnitude in
comparison with t = 30 µs. If assuming that most of the
current at this stage in the pulse runs in the azimuthal direction
in a plasma torus (inner radius 3.5 cm and outer radius 7.5 cm)
with its center located just below z = 4 cm and with the
above given current density, then the total azimuthal current
is approximately 28 A, which is roughly 20% of the discharge
current.
After t = 85 µs J z is found to increase faster than J ϕ , as
seen in figures 4(c) and (d), meaning that there is a comparably
lower Hall parameter ω ge τ EFF in this time interval, which will
be further analyzed in section 3.3. J ϕ still preserves the
characteristic toroidal current flow, which is further expanded
in space as the internal current densities reach a second
maximum at t = 130 µs seen in figure 4(e). J ϕ above the
race track at z ≈ 4 cm is found to be more than ten times
larger than J z .
In figures 4(a)-(e) of J z two current-intense areas can be
identified: (1) at z ∼ 4 cm and ρ ∼ 0 cm as well as (2) at
z ∼ 4 cm and ρ ∼ 7.5 cm. These must be mainly field-aligned
currents J , since the magnetic field lines at these locations
run almost perpendicular to the magnetron surface, as can be
seen in figure 5. In order to study the edge effects of the cross-
B electron transport it is therefore necessary to investigate
the radial component of the current density distribution. Only
above the target race track, where a large part of the cross-B
current is carried, J ϕ /J z ≈ ω ge τ EFF is valid, and will be used
in the analysis below.
Another way of illustrating the measured current density
dynamics from ignition, via peak to decay of the HiPIMS
discharge, is to look at the net current flow across the different
boundaries of the investigated cylindrical volume (4
z
8 cm and 0
ρ
7.5 cm). These currents have been
calculated from the data in figures 4(a)-(c) using Kirchhoff's
current law and are given in figure 5 as a percentage of the

(c) 85 µs (d) 100 µs and (e) 130 µs after pulse initiation. Notice that the current density values in figures 4(b)-(e) are higher compared with
figure 4(a), which is represented by an approximate scale factor in the upper left corner. The hatched area in the right panel of figure 4(a)
indicates that no current ratio could be established here due to a zero J z value.

Figure 5. Analysis of the measured current densities from figure 4
in terms of how the current is transported across the investigated
region. (a) At t = 30 µs , during the breakdown phase, (b) at
t = 60 µs during the maximum of the discharge current and (c) at
t = 85 µs during the decay of the HiPIMS discharge current. The
net current flow across the different boundaries of two cylindrical
volumes in the discharge, between z coordinates 0-4 cm and
4-8 cm, respectively, is shown. The areas of the block arrows are
proportional to the currents, which are also given as a percentage of
the discharge current. The ellipses above the target race track
represent cross sections of the dense plasma torus also seen in the J ϕ
plots of figure 4 (left panels).
discharge current. The block arrows show the total current I
across the indicated surface (i.e. not the current density J ).
A few things can be noted: (1) during the rise of the pulse,
most of the discharge current crosses the B-field radially and
close to the target surface (z < 4 cm). As the pulse evolves,
this fraction decreases dramatically (only 12% at t = 85 µs).
(2) Cross-B current transport across the lower disk (z = 4 cm,
0 ρ 7.5 cm) is not detected during the rise of the pulse but
grows to be the dominant fraction of the measured total current
as the discharge decay phase is reached (88% at t = 85 µs).
(3) There is a radial current reversal between 60 and 85 µs
across the cylinder surface (4
z
8 cm, ρ = 7.5 cm),
which is analyzed in more detail in the next section.
3.2. Analysis of the current system in the bulk plasma
Analysis of the data in figures 4(a)-(c) shows that the internal
currents in the volume of the discharge go through a sequence
of configurations during the pulse. We propose that this
complex time evolution be suitably analyzed in three types of
current systems, called I, II (subdivided into IIa, IIb, IIc) and
III that are shown in figure 6 and summarized in table 2. It will
be shown that a suitable superposition of these current systems
can describe the internal current dynamics for any given time
during the HiPIMS discharge.
We propose that that the redistribution of currents
observed in figure 5 can be understood in terms of the current
systems of figure 6 as follows:
(1) Each current pulse starts with an ignition phase during
which there is negligible plasma in the bulk volume of
the vessel. Since the vacuum electric field is strongest in
the vicinity of the anode ring of the magnetron, this is a
natural place of ignition, beginning as a localized glow
discharge close to the target surface. Without plasma in
the bulk volume, the electrons can in this ignition phase
only go in a current system of type I to the anode ring.
This is why there is a strong radial current close to the
target surface during the rise of the HiPIMS pulse, as seen
in figure 5(a).
(2) The next phase is the bulk plasma breakdown. Secondary
electrons, and electrons created in the ionization region
close to the target, are accelerated out along the magnetic
field into the bulk volume and begin to ionize the neutral
gas. When the bulk plasma density has built up sufficiently
to admit current closure across B at high z, a current
system of types IIa-IIc is added to the overall current
distribution (figure 5(b)). At 30 µs, type IIa carries 20%
of the discharge current (see figure 5(a)). In the current
system types IIa and IIb, the transport of electrons along
B should be associated with two J z current maxima at
z ≈ 4 cm: one around ρ = 0 cm and another around
ρ ≈ 8 cm, where the magnetic field lines are aligned in
the z direction. Both J z maxima are clearly present in the
experimental data (middle panel of figure 4(a)).
(3) The final phase is establishing a steady state. As can
be seen in the middle panels of figures 4(a)-(e) there
is a transition in J z from the above-described maxima
at the center and edge of the target (types IIa and IIb
in figure 6(b)) to a more evenly distributed axial current
density (t
85 µs), indicating an increased cross-
B transport above the race track (types IIc and III).
Eventually, approaching the steady state, a type III current

Figure 6. The charged particle transport in three types of current
systems in the axial-radial plane schematically drawn in the
topology of the magnetron. A dashed-line rectangle encloses the
area of measurements in figure 4. The hatched area to the lower
right denotes the grounded anode ring. It is intersected by the 'first
grounded magnetic field line'. The electrons must cross this field
line in order to close the electric circuit. (a) Current system of type
I, (b) current systems of types IIa-IIc, and (c) current system of type
III. The curves to the left in panels (b) and (c) show schematically
the current in the z direction above the race track for current types
IIa-IIc and III; in current system type I, that current is zero for all z.
system is dominating. At this stage the plasma density
above the race track is high enough that this route is the
easiest for the electron current to cross the magnetic field
lines. The gradual change of current systems has been
estimated from the data in figure 5 and is summarized in
figure 7, from which it can be concluded that steady state
is approached somewhere around 85-100 µs. Due to the
short pulse length in this experiment no real steady state
situation is established, since the discharge goes into the
decay phase.
An unexplained feature during the decay phase is the second
axial as well as azimuthal current peak seen for the azimuthal
case in figure 3 (t = 130 µs). At this point the axial current

Figure 7. A schematic illustration of the gradual change between
current systems of types I, IIa, and the sum of the remaining types
IIb-III, as deduced from the data in figure 5.
density is still high (middle panel of figure 4(e)), which is out
of phase with the decreasing discharge current (I D ∼ 60 A)
and clearly very different to the ignition phase current density
distribution seen in the middle panel of figure 4(a). It might be
that both the azimuthal and the cross-B current are increasingly
concentrated in the region above the race track because the
plasma density still rises there. Similar double peak structures
were observed by Bohlmark et al [11] when investigating time-
dependent variations of the magnetic field on the same device.
The authors ascribe this phenomenon as related to an interplay
between the electric field (−z) and the plasma pressure (+z),
where the electric field is strongly reduced in the decay phase
of the HiPIMS pulse, and thereby causing an expansion of the
dense plasma torus.
3.3. Current ratio
The spatially resolved current density ratio J ϕ /J z is shown
in the right hand panels of figures 4(a)-(e). The reason for
investigating this ratio is the previously discussed anomalous
cross-B transport of electrons, which has been described in
several earlier works [4, 10, 12, 14, 15]. A short summary of
this particular transport mechanism is given below to facilitate
the discussion of the results that follow.
In the HiPIMS plasma the classical resistivity, governing
the transport properties, is modified by the existence of a
text.note:
Plasma Sources Sci. Technol. 20 (2011) 045003
D Lundin et al
text.body:
plasma instability [10], driven by the azimuthal current. The
correlation between oscillating n e and E ϕ results in azimuthal
forces of opposite sign on the electron and ion populations.
Macroscopically, this is equivalent to an anomalous cross-B
resistivity, η ⊥ = n e E ϕ /(J ϕ n e ) [4]. The effective electron
momentum transfer time, often called the effective electron
collision time, τ EFF , is related to the cross-B resistivity through
η ⊥ =
m e
τ EFF e 2 n e
=
B
ω ge τ EFF en e
,
(2)
where the electron angular gyrofrequency is written as ω ge =
eB/m e [19]. In the magnetron geometry, the product ω ge τ EFF
can be found from a macroscopic measurement of the current
density ratio J ϕ /J D⊥ = ω ge τ EFF (where it is assumed that
J D⊥ is carried by electrons) [12, 14]. This means that a low
ratio of J ϕ /J D⊥ (or equivalently a low ω ge τ EFF ) is the result
of increased transverse resistivity and thereby increased cross-
B conductivity and diffusion of electrons. As mentioned in
the introduction, earlier estimates of J ϕ /J D⊥ in magnetrons
show values that are around 2 in HiPIMS [10, 11] and in the
range 8-30 in DCMS discharges [12, 13]. The estimates in
HiPIMS discharges are, however, based on assumptions about
the spatial distribution of J z over magnetic flux surfaces, and
furthermore are time averages around the time of the discharge
current maximum. Through the use of the Rogowski probe
these limitations have been overcome and the first time and
space resolved current density ratios are here presented. As
described above, the current density measurements cover only
J ϕ and J z (not J r ), and ω ge τ EFF can only be obtained above the
race track region, where the magnetic field is parallel to the
target surface.
Figure 8 shows J ϕ /J z above the race track for times 30,
60, 85, 100 and 130 µs based on the results in the right panels
of figures 4(a)-(e). The following observations can be made:
(1) there are small variations in time, where the values stay
within a factor of two from the average indicated by a solid
line. The lowest ω ge τ EFF values are found at the times of
the transition regions of the internal current measurements,
i.e. points (a), (c) and (d) in figure 3 (t = 30 µs , 85 µs
and 100 µs respectively). (2) There is a systematic spatial
variation. Only around z ∼ 7-8 cm are the earlier reported
low values ω ge τ EFF ≈ 2 recovered. Closer to the target,
ω ge τ EFF increases with decreasing z and values approaching the
Bohm range are found. (3) A comparison with the magnetic
field strength B(z) shows that ω ge τ EFF scales approximately
as 1/B, as expected from classical collisions with constant
τ EFF . However, classical collisions (also plotted for reference
in figure 8) are over the whole range of z and at all times about
a constant factor of 8 too infrequent. Further analysis of this
topic is postponed until we have a firmer experimental basis,
including measurements of the J r component.
4. Conclusions
The internal current densities J ϕ and J z have been successfully
measured in a HiPIMS discharge using Rogowski coils. From
the spatially and temporally resolved data it is seen that the
current density evolution can be characterized by a gradually
(a)
(b)
(c)
(b)
(c)
Bohm
super-Bohm
Bohm
super-Bohm
J
ϕ /J
z
J
ϕ /J
z
Figure 8. Measurements of J ϕ /J z ≈ ω ge τ EFF above the race track, at
the times (a)-(e) (figure 4). The curve marked (a) is the average of
the experimental data. For reference, two values of classical
ω ge τ class. are also given: classical electron-neutral collisions (b), and
combined electron-neutral and Coulomb collisions (c), as well as
the Bohm-value ω ge τ class. = 16 (dashed). The Bohm region,
8 < ω ge τ EFF < 30, as well as the faster-than-Bohm region
(super-Bohm), 1.5 < ω ge τ EFF < 5.5, appear as shaded areas. The
Coulomb collision rate is based on the measurements by
Sigurjonsson of T e and n e [20]. The bottom panel displays the same
data as the top panel, but with an increased range of J ϕ /J z .
changing superposition of three different types of current
systems operating during the pulse: types I, IIa-IIc and type
III, with which the development of the pulsed plasma can
be described in a simple phenomenological model. Also
the mechanisms of current transport along as well as across
magnetic field lines are covered in the present description.
Furthermore, the current density ratio, J ϕ /J D , has also been
calculated due to its importance for characterizing the cross-B
electron transport in these types of discharges. It was found that
faster-than-Bohm cross-B electron transport is operating in
the HiPIMS discharge, in particular during the internal current
transient regimes for z > 6 cm, whereas Bohm diffusion is
approached for z < 5 cm.

Acknowledgments
The authors gratefully thank Michael Raadu for valuable
discussions, and Petter Larsson for technical assistance in the
manufacturing of the Rogowski probes. This work was partly
supported by the Swedish Research Council and the Swedish
Foundation for Strategic Research.
